column1: I was 14
column2: and walking home from school. A well-dressed man who looked like he was in his early 20s was walking towards me. I was lost in my own thoughts when I was walking
column3: and as our paths crossed
column4: he reached out and groped my chest. The moment this happened
column5: I was confused for a second and stood frozen to the ground
column6: not knowing how to react. I wheeled back
column7: only to see the guy walking away casually
column9: because he assumed I wouldn't do much. I threw my only weapon
column10: a 500 ml nearly-empty plastic water bottle aimed straight for his head. My aim being so excellent
column11: it went a few metres past his head
column12: and he ended up tripping on the bottle
column13: falling to the ground. I ran up to him
column14: landed good kicks in his groin
column16: called for help. Some people stopped their cars
column17: asked me if I was alright
column20: and even offered him advice. He ended up in tears and apologized. People talked me out of filing an FIR because they said it would be a hassling affair. I believed it and moved on. One less pervert in the world.

column1: I had a friend who worked as a flight attendant and she got into a mild argument with a guy who insisted on having EVERYTHING that was free or complimentary on the flight. He was highly annoying and constantly asked crew for stuff. If he saw someone next to him get something
column2: he wanted it too. At one point during the flight a lady asked for a sanitary pad to help her with an 'emergency' situation. He insisted he should have one too - cos you know
column3: it's free
column4: right?. My friend tried to reason with him. I'm not sure if his English was 100%
column5: because he insisted again and seemed to assume the pad was one of these... A sleep mask. Upon receiving his sanitary pad he proceeded to peel the paper backing off and expose the sticky side; he stuck the thing over his eyes and soon afterwards fell asleep... THE END.

column1: Do you know if you switched a chicken egg with that of a duck without the hen noticing
column2: what would happen?. My dad grew up farming banty chickens and ducks. Banty chickens are excellent and responsible egg layers
column3: and will not give up until their eggs hatch. When they have a “miscarriage”
column4: they just don't stop trying to lay them. Ducks
column5: on the other hand
column6: quickly loose interest in laying their eggs and wander off. In order to sustain the ducks
column7: my dad’s job was to collect duck eggs and place them under banty chickens. When they hatched
column8: the banty chickens couldn't tell the difference. But the poor ducklings had a hard time understanding “mom”. Banty chickens dart around eating insects; the ducklings’ natural instinct is to follow their mother in a neat line. Now imagine a bunch of ducklings trying to make a neat line behind their difficult to follow
column10: and then comes drinking from the pond. A banty chicken will lead her chicks to the pond
column11: and everyone takes a few sips and then proceeds darting about after insects. When a duck goes to the pond with her ducklings
column12: they all just wade in and sip water as they swim around. Now when a banty chicken with ducklings leads everyone to the pond for a few sips of water
column13: all the ducklings instinctively wade in and start swimming around. The poor mother
column14: unaware of her children's swimming abilities
column15: then flips out and runs in circles around the pond frantically clucking at them. All the while
column16: the ducklings swim around wondering “What's up with mom?”.

column1: This is a story about a lovely thing a child has said. Do you know the marshmallow test? You give a child a marshmallow
column2: and then say that if she (Layla
column3: in this case) could keep from eating it for 10 minutes
column4: you'll give her a second. So I tried that test with my granddaughter (not with marshmallows
column5: but with chocolate
column6: which she likes much more). According to extensive experiments
column7: children who "pass" the "marshmallow test" are far more successful in later life. They have learned a fundamental truth in life
column8: that delayed gratification can lead to a far better long-term outcome. She sat and watched the chocolate. The 10-minute hourglass finally emptied
column9: and she had succeeded. She asked for her second piece of chocolate.  I gave it to her
column10: and she now had two in her hand. That's when she looked up at me and asked
column13: from that moment on I would readily give my life for her.

column1: I’m 21 years old and working at Fridays. One night this woman comes in with three small children. As a waiter
column2: I could usually tell who is going to tip well and who is going tip not at all. I definitely got the latter vibe from her. She asked about the price of everything on the menu
column3: she ordered only water to drink. She wasn’t interested in appetizers. At one point her daughter asked her (very politely) if she could have milk. The woman pulled out her coin purse and counted up her change before saying yes. Now I am convinced I’m not getting a tip
column4: but they were very nice and pleasant to serve so I don’t even think twice about it. At the end of the meal she paid entirely in quarters. When I went back to bus the table
column5: to my surprise
column6: there was a stack of quarters left for me. It amounted to $8
column7: or about 25% of the meal. Here was a woman who had to count her money before ordering her daughter a chocolate milk because she wanted to make sure she still had enough to tip me generously. Was it the largest tip I ever got? No
column8: but it’s the only one I remember all these years later.

column1: My mentor
column2: the great Nobel Laureate Luis Alvarez was dying of cancer
column3: but I could tell that he was more concerned about his mental state. I assured him his wits were all there
column4: but he had watched his dad suffer from Alzheimers
column5: and he didn’t seem convinced. Then I stumbled upon a small optical device
column6: a display that used an array of tiny lenses to produce a wonderful and beautiful Moire pattern. That was all I could figure out about it; just exactly how did it really work? I knew that Alvarez had an enormous understanding of classical optics
column7: and he loved the subject. So I brought him the device
column8: told him about my Moire thoughts
column9: but expressed my confusion. He took it from my hand
column13: and said he would think about it. I left it with him. Two days later I visited again
column14: and he proudly explained to me how it worked. I was delighted
column15: but (I think) not as delighted as he was. He knew the problem was challenging; he knew I had tried and failed to understand it. He had figured out its clever and non-intuitive design. Nothing less than that could have convinced him that his mental abilities were undiminished. I still take pleasure in my memory of the joy that brought to him.

column1: A sales rep
column2: an administration clerk
column3: and the manager are walking to lunch when they find an antique oil lamp. They rub it and a Genie comes out. The Genie says
column4: “I’ll give each of you just one wish”. “Me first
column5: Me first!” says the administration clerk. “I want to be in the Bahamas
column6: driving a speedboat
column7: without a care in the world”. Poof! She’s gone. “Me next
column8: Me next!” says the sales rep. “I want to be in Hawaii
column9: relaxing on the beach with my personal masseuse
column10: an endless supply of Pina Coladas and the love of my life”. Poof! He’s gone. “OK
column12: ” the Genie says to the manager. The manager says
column13: “I want those two back in the office after lunch.”

column1: My girlfriend and I went to watch Avatar when it was released. Apparently
column2: it was her first 3D movie experience and God was she excited. When she came out of the theater
column3: visibly overwhelmed
column4: she asked me
column5: "Don't you think the world would be much more beautiful if we could see it in 3D?". I drank myself to death that night.

column1: Each time you board a plane and look for your seat
column2: a small part of you is begging to be seated beside someone interesting. After spending hours of flying besides snoring
column3: noisy and boring old people
column4: this time I finally found a skinny girl in her mid twenties seated beside me. For once I was seated with someone who smelled nice
column5: had skinny elbows
column6: and seemed likely to stay up during the flight. As soon as the safety belt sign went off
column7: she took out her brand new "laminated" laptop with Windows 8 and started fiddling with it. After hopelessly struggling with it for over ten minutes
column10: can you help me out with this?". "Of course
column12: always interested to play around with the then newly released Windows 8. "I am unable to catch wi-fi signals on this?". I look at her
column13: with all my shock and horror clearly visible on my face
column16: how on earth would you get wi-fi here??". But she thought she was wiser
column18: which almost made me smash my head on her laptop
column21: No?". I had just hit the rock bottom of tech-lowness in my life

column1: I was chatting with a stranger at a party; he was very curious about physics. It was time to sit down and eat
column2: and several of my friends urged me to take a seat with them; but there was only one seat. I thought it would be rude to leave my conversation
column3: so I declined and sat with the stranger I had been talking to. We continued to talk through the lunch. Then
column4: at the end
column5: he said
column6: "I assume you get all the financial support you need from the federal government". I said no; because my kind of research was typically in fields that they didn't support. He continued
column7: "I run a small family foundation; Could we help support your research?". That was 15 years ago
column8: and his foundation has given us substantial help every year.

column1: When I was in high school our physics teacher gave us a challenge that involved making a paper air plane of any shape. The only objective was to get it to fly as far as possible. I had some paper air plane making skills so I made the best plane I could and it flew pretty far. One guy made the greatest
column2: yet simplest paper airplane of all time. He stood there at the starting line with a regular piece of paper. Some classmates scratched their head while silently chuckling to themselves. Moments later he took the flat piece of paper
column3: crumpled it up
column4: and threw it down the hall way. He beat the class with ease. Some of the students got mad and said that he cheated. The physics teacher said
column5: "How so? I said it could be any shape; A paper ball is indeed a shape". He won the contest with flying colors. As Arthur Schopenhauer said: "Talent hits a target no one else can hit; Genius hits a target no one else can see". I still regard this classmate as a genius.

column1: A navy captain is alerted by his First Mate that there is a pirate ship coming towards his position. He asks a sailor to get him his red shirt.  The captain was asked
column2: “Why do you need a red shirt?”. The Captain replies
column3: “So that when I bleed
column4: you guys don’t notice and aren’s discouraged”. They fight off the pirates eventually. The very next day
column5: the Captain is alerted that 50 pirate ships are coming towards their boat. He yells
column6: “Get me my brown pants!”

column1: A couple going on vacation but his wife was on a business trip so he went to the destination first and his wife would meet him the next day. When he reached his hotel
column2: he decided to send his wife a quick email. Unfortunately
column3: when typing her address
column4: he mistyped a letter and his note was directed instead to an elderly preacher’s wife whose husband had passed away only the day before. When the grieving widow checked her email
column5: she took one look at the monitor
column6: let out a piercing scream
column7: and fell to the floor in a dead faint. At the sound
column8: her family rushed into the room and saw this note on the screen: Dearest Wife
column9: Just got checked in. Everything prepared for your arrival tomorrow. PS Sure is hot down here.

column1: 3 men died and went up to heaven. The guy at the gate said “The better you were to your wife
column2: the better kind of car you’ll get”. The first guy was very loyal to his wife and got a Ferrari. The second man fought with his wife so he got a broken down car. The last guy cheated on his wife dozens of times so he got a scooter. One day the guy on the scooter saw the guy in the Ferrari crying. He asked him
column3: “Why are you crying?”. He answered
column4: “I just saw my wife on roller skates.”

column5: as there are really very few openings in comparison with the number of girls who apply."

column5: "No

column1: We were flying to CA while I was breastfeeding our second daughter

column3: smiled and then LICKED IT OFF. He said
column4: "Yum
column5: just right!" and had no idea it was my breastmilk. I just about wet my pants. What a nice man!

column1: I am a white american woman. I was engaged with an African-American man and I got pregnant. We broke up. I had many thoughts about whether keeping the baby or not. Many reasons were making me doubt about what to do. Especially
column2: I am well aware about the prejuduces so common in the white american community in which I live. My son will be half-black. Prejudices around him will make his life hard and I won't be able to transmit him the beautiful African America culture that he should have access to. I'm sure his dad won't be able to raise him alone in another community. I decided to give him for adoption. The dad strongly disagrees. But I prefer him to live in a welcoming African-American family
column3: rather than in my culture full stereotypes and hate.

column1: There was a story of a little girl named Liza who was suffering from a disease and needed blood from her five-year-old brother
column2: who had miraculously survived the same disease and had developed the antibodies needed to combat the illness. The doctor explained the situation to her little brother
column3: and asked the boy if he would be willing to give his blood to his sister. I saw him hesitate for only a moment before taking a deep breath and saying
column4: “Yes
column5: I’ll do it if it will save Liza”. As the transfusion progressed
column6: he lay in bed next to his sister and smiled
column7: as we all did
column8: seeing the color returning to her cheeks. Then his face grew pale and his smile faded. He looked up at the doctor and asked with a trembling voice
column9: “Will I start to die right away?”. Being young
column10: the boy had misunderstood the doctor; he thought he was going to have to give her all his blood.

column1: A curious child asked his mother: “Mommy
column2: why are some of your hairs turning grey?”. The mother tried to use this occasion to teach her child: “It is because of you
column3: dear: every bad action of yours will turn one of my hairs grey!”. The child replied innocently: “Now I know why grandmother has only grey hairs on her head.”

column12: yes I did! But I bet her hiccups are gone now!"

column5: "I just wanted to show you what it feels like when I'm driving."

column3: "Now listen
column4: when I die

column9: just before the undertakers got ready to close the casket

column13: I promised. I'm a good person. I can't lie. I promised him that I was going to put that money in that casket with him." "You mean to tell me you put every cent of his money in the casket with him?" "I sure did
column14: said the wife. I got it all together
column15: put it into my account and I wrote him a check."

column3: however

column6: the woman went home with him that evening and
column7: three days later she became his stepmother. Women are so much smarter than men.

column1: One day my mother was out and my dad was in charge of me. I was maybe 2 1/2 years old and had just recovered from an accident. Someone had given me a little 'tea set' as a get-well gift and it was one of my favorite toys. Daddy was in the living room engrossed in the evening news when I brought Daddy a little cup of "tea
column2: which was just water. After several cups of tea and lots of praise for such yummy tea, my Mom came home. My Dad made her wait in the living room to watch me bring him a cup of tea, because it was just the cutest thing!" My Mom waited
column3: and sure enough
column4: here I come down the hall with a cup of tea for Daddy and she watched him drink it up. Then she says
